awd_titl_txt: TWC: Small: Collaborative: Advancing Anonymity Against an AS-level Adversary
awd_abstract_narration:
Autonomous systems (AS) are key building blocks of the Internet's routing infrastructure.  Surveillance of AS may allow large-scale monitoring of Internet users. Those who aim to protect the privacy of their online communications may turn to anonymity systems like Tor, but Tor is not designed to protect against such AS-level adversaries. AS-level adversaries present unique challenges for the design of robust anonymity systems and present a very different threat model from the ones used to design and study systems like Tor. Thus, new research is needed to understand this threat and to defend against it. 

This project is investigating the design of anonymity systems that are resilient against AS-level adversaries. First, the project aims to quantify the capabilities of AS-level adversaries, who are powerful eavesdroppers and also capable of active attacks, but also have some limitations in practice. Second, the project is designing new route-selection strategies for anonymity systems that can limit how much of the anonymized traffic the AS-level adversary can observe and attack. Finally, the project is investigating how anonymity systems can hinder an AS-level adversaries' ability to analyze encrypted traffic by injecting spurious cover traffic and timing delays. The findings and new anonymity system designs from this research will impact the privacy of a broad class of users in the context of forms of large-scale monitoring of online communications.

por.por_cntn:
The Tor anonymity system provides privacy and security to millions ofusers around the world, routing their communications through a path ofproxies selected from a large set of volunteer-run nodes. This projectexamined the implications of dynamic adversaries of Tor who couldmanipulate routing in the Internet and try to deanonymize users. Itfurther explored the broader consequences of attacks that leverage thedynamic, variable aspects of systems.


First, the project examined website fingerprinting attacks, in which aneavesdropper who can see the user's encrypted traffic uses machinelearning to identify that traffic's destination. Initial investigationsthat showed promise in lightweight defenses yielded to new findings ofpowerful new attack methods using more advanced machine-learningtechniques. The project showed the importance of designing against thesenovel attack methods.


Second, the project studied ways to select paths of Tor proxies thatavoid potential eavesdropping by a single network on the Internet. SinceTor is already slow for users, prior methods that added significantdelay to the start of connections were not reasonable to deploy. Theproject identified a new method of selecting safer Tor paths withoutknowing the user's intended destination, significantly improvingperformance over prior methods. Building on this finding, the projectfurther designed a technique based on machine learning to both selectTor paths for greater performance without losing anonymity and tomeasure potential anonymity loss from any path selection technique.


Third, the project leveraged the ideas of network location to design asecurity improvement to how Tor selects the first proxy on the user'sTor path. Using the same proxy every time enhances security against someattacks but also facilitates other attacks. A balanced approach thatoffers good security against both types of attacks is to create sets ofproxies and assign groups of users to select their proxies from one setevery time. The project showed how a naive approach to creating andmaintaining the sets would allow an attacker to infiltrate many sets andobserve much more traffic than its resources should allow. It thenexamined a new technique for set creation and maintenance based onnetwork location, finding that this approach greatly mitigated theattack.


Finally, the project took the core idea of an attacker modifying itsresources and actions over time to explore dynamic attacks in P2P andsocial networks. These systems require defenses against Sybil attacks,in which the attacker creates many fake identifies to establish anoutsized presence in the network and thereby control key systemactivites. The project identified sources of churn in these networksthat can lead to Sybil defenses being undermined over time. It foundsignificant sources of vulnerability that are in some casesfundamentally difficult to defend against. Securing systems againstattacks like these requires careful attention to how designs change overtime.

Modified by: Jiang Ming
